entry.title: Re: Error while testing-'Electronic Payment File - Receiv...
entry.content:
Good day @bcrao 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Incoming Payments with Electronic Bank Statements, Process Payment Files

Payments and Bank Communication in S/4HANA Cloud, In-House Banking Integration to Financial Accounting Systems

To summarise, when testing the Electronic Payment File ‚Äì Receive AP in public cloud and you get the error you mentioned, it means your inbound XML is missing the required MessageHeader node defined in the API schema. To fix it, i suggest:

  • You ensure your payload contains <MessageHeader> and <PaymentFile> blocks.
  • Encode the file content in Base64.
  • Verify your BCM configuration (file type, inbound channel, and bank settings).
  • Use the official API schema from SAP API HUB for payload validation.

This will ensure you inbound file gets accepted by BCM and visible in ‚ÄúBank Communication Monitor‚Äù

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Create transparency across your SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environments
entry.content:
Once SAP BTP has been established as platform for side-by-side extensions to your SAP solutions, it becomes important to keep an overview of the deployed extensions. Earlier this year, I blogged about the discovery of SAP Build projects to push them into the SAP discovery inbox of SAP LeanIX. Now I am excited to share with you that we just released the next step in our discovery journey: The discovery of applications deployed to SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment. This includes their service bindings, the used Cloud Foundry buildpack versions, and a grouping if multi target applications (MTA) were deployed.

What you gain

For you as enterprise architect, this means you can easily get an overview of all the deployed applications across the whole SAP BTP global account. If your company has more than one global account in place, the integration can be setup several times and all discoveries will be sent to LeanIX‚Äô ‚ÄúSAP discover inbox‚Äù. After adding applications relevant for your productive landscape to your inventory, you can easily browse through the deployed apps without the need of access to the SAP BTP subaccounts. Following the SAP LeanIX modeling guidelines, applications are related to platform fact sheets which represent the global- and subaccounts. Furthermore, service bindings to SAP BTP services are modeled as IT Components.

Based on customer feedback, the SAP discovery inbox will suggest an IT Component based on the used Cloud Foundry buildpack version.
Imagine that with one click, you can see which Cloud Foundry deployments across your SAP BTP landscape are using an outdated buildpack version!

This is what you need

The setup is described in SAP Help Portal, but I want to point out the headlines here:

  • What you need is a platform user in your tenant of the SAP Cloud Identity Service, for which the generation and authentication with certificates is enabled. Trust between the IAS tenant and the SAP BTP global- and subaccounts needs to be established.
  • Your development teams need to add this platform user to all respective Cloud Foundry organizations and spaces which should be crawled. We recommend adding this user to the spaces which include your productively used applications.
  • With this platform user, its certificate & related password, the list of used Cloud Foundry API Servers, and a service key to SAP Cloud Management Service, you are good to go. SAP LeanIX will start fetching all deployments, service bindings, and buildpacks.

Feedback is welcome!

Try it out and let me know your feedback! The roadmap item includes a link for finding a joint time to talk. Furthermore, you can leave a comment here or meet me at ASUG Tech Connect this week in Louisville, KY.

entry.title: Re: Guidance for Creating Sales Order from External Syste...
entry.content:
Good day @Thanushree1999 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV, Error 403 when Create Sales Order using API_SALES_ORDER_SRV

Create Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0109, Configuring the OAuth 2.0 Client

Sales Order creation via OData API calls

https://help.sap.com/viewer/DRAFT/0f9408e4921e4ba3bb4a7a1f75f837a7/1811.500/en-US/d9494291232f416fb7...

To summarise, in public cloud, the easiest way to create Sales Order from an external system is by using the standard A2X API (API_SALES_ORDER_SRV) with OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials authentication. Best practice is to simply: Create a communication arrangement (which you have already done), generate an OAuth token, POST a JSON payload to /A_SalesOrder, Map external fields to standard S4H fields, optionally use SAP Cloud Integration or Groovy scripts for dynamic field mapping.

This approach is fully clean core complaint, secure, and scalable for automation. For testing, Postman + OAuth token is sufficient. For Production, integrate through SAP BTP/CPI for dynamic payload handling and monitoring.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BAdI that allows modification of standard fields in t...
entry.content:
Good day @Patricia122023 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Blog: Explore Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for SAP S/4HANA Cloud on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Extensibility: Production Order Confirmation, Manage Production Orders

Extending Existing SAP Solutions Using SAP BTP

In summary, there is no released BAdI equivalent to WORKORDER_UPDATE that allows modifying standards field in the production order header at release in public cloud. SAP restricts this to maintain the clean core. Instead, you should consider using:

  • The Manage Production Orders (A2X API) to update standard header fields externally, or
  • The BD_MFGORDER_MODIFY_CUST_FIELDS BAdI to populate custom fields internally.

Whilst you cannot modify the standard order header directly, there are clean-core-compliant workarounds such as using Process Automation you may consider. You can use SAP Build Process Automation or SAP Cloud ALM process automation to:

  • Detect the order release event (via Event Mesh/Business Event ManufacturingOrder.Release).
  • Use BTP integration flow (iFlow) or REST API call to the ‚ÄúManage Production Orders (A2X API_MFG_ORDER) service.
  • Update the order‚Äôs batch field using the API, this API supports PATCH operations in header data.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP for Me S-user category is Customer, how to change it to Partner?
entry.content:
SAP for Me S-user category is Customer, but my colleague needs the S-user category Partner.

How to change it to Partner? Is it possible?

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP for Me S-user category is Customer, how to change...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Kindly know the S-user category cannot be changed from Customer to Partner, and vice-versa.

This is documented in KBA 3553147 - Can the S-user ID "Type" (Customer/Partner) be changed in the Profile application in SAP for Me?

If you need an S-user with category Partner, then could you pls contact the SAP Partner support team via the channel introduced in KBA 1848459? S-user with category Partner needs to be created on the PartnerEdge portal.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Error encountered while uploading Variable Pay Template
entry.content:
Hi @Singh_28 

Release tip and tricks for Compensation experts that need to do a cutover from a preview environment to a production environment by November 14-15 when 2H 2025 gets rolled out to Production environments:

  •  In order to successfully import a compensation or variable pay template xml to production you will need to first search in the exported template from the preview environment for [hideInProfile="false" hideInForm="false"] and replace with blanks (through xml editor) otherwise you will get error messages in provisioning (the error message might not be specific to this but this is the root cause).

from here.

Best,

Xavier

entry.title: Re: Question about running Job from Subaccount B to Appli...
entry.content:
Hello,

Since its different sub-accounts, the XSUAA instance will be different and the job scheduler of one subaccount cannot authenticate the app in other account. XSUAA instances are isolated per subaccount.

For B to A calls, you need a technical client in A (with the right scopes), and B‚Äôs Job/Service must authenticate using that.

entry.title: Why Choose SAP Business One Over Traditional ERP for SMEs?
entry.content:
Why Choose SAP Business One Over Traditional ERP for SMEs?

Article Teaser:
Small and mid-sized businesses often struggle with large ERP systems built for big corporations. SAP Business One offers a leaner, smarter alternative designed specifically for SMEs. But what makes it stand out? Let‚Äôs explore the differences and why it often wins.

A Simple View: Traditional ERP vs SAP Business One

Traditional ERPs are powerful but they come with high cost, long setup time, and heavy processes. For many SMEs, this means delays and overhead.

SAP Business One is built for smaller operations. It connects finance, sales, inventory and operations in one system. It supports on-premise or cloud deployment. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

Key Advantages for SMEs

  • Speed and Cost-Efficiency: SAP Business One uses fewer resources to deploy and maintain. SMEs can start faster and without heavy budgets. 
  • Built-In Modules for Core Functions: Finance, CRM, inventory, production and reporting all in one system. This reduces silos and errors.
  • Real-Time Insights and Reporting: Leaders make decisions quickly based on live data, not just past reports. 
  • Scalability and Flexibility: Though built for SMEs, the system grows with you adding users or modules as needed. 

When Traditional ERP Still Makes Sense

If your business is very large, highly global, or has ultra-complex processes, a full enterprise ERP might still be the right choice. But for most SMEs needing speed, clarity and cost control, SAP Business One hits the balance.

Practical Example

Imagine an SME with multiple warehouses, global sales, and service calls. With SAP Business One you get:

  • Visible inventory across locations.
  • Sales orders are linked directly to stock and deliveries.
  • Finance sees profit by product, region, or season in a few clicks.
  • Compliance and audits are easier because data is in one system.

Instead of juggling spreadsheets and multiple tools, everything lives in one system made for your size.

Conclusion

For SMEs seeking a business system that delivers strength without the overhead of full enterprise ERP, SAP Business One offers a compelling option. It connects core functions, gives live data to decision-makers, scales with growth, and keeps costs in check.

entry.title: Is a special SAP license required for Power Automate RPA, or is a standard Named User sufficient?
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

Context : We use Power Automate Desktop (PAD) to automate SAP ECC via SAP GUI Scripting for report export and MB21 posting (GUI only; no API/connector).

Our understanding:

  • Because access is via SAP GUI (direct), the bot should be licensed as a standard SAP Named User (BOT account), not as an SAP ‚ÄúRPA user‚Äù and not under Digital/Indirect Access (that would apply if we used non-SAP front-ends/API creating the 9 Digital Access document types).

  • Microsoft licensing is separate: cloud scheduling/unattended would require Power Automate Premium. (Today we‚Äôre attended/manual.)

Questions to confirm (please answer Yes/No):

  1. For PAD via SAP GUI, is a special SAP RPA license required? Or is a standard Named User for the BOT account sufficient under our contract?

  2. Which Named User class should we assign to the BOT (Professional vs Limited), given it creates MB21 reservations?

  3. Can we proceed to create a dedicated BOT account (Dialog or Service) with least-privilege roles and restrict GUI Scripting (S_SCR) to this BOT only?

  4. If in the future we switch to API/connector flows, should we then evaluate Digital Access (document-based) separately?

If this looks right, we‚Äôll proceed with a BOT Named User and keep runs attended until any Premium licensing is approved.

Thanks!

Richard

entry.title: Setting Up MCP Servers for SAP Development ‚Äî UI5, CDS, and Fiori
entry.content:
The way we build SAP applications is changing fast. With Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers, we can now give our AI-assisted tools the context they need to work with our SAP stack ‚Äî not just around it.

In simple terms, MCP servers act as tool connectors for AI agents, editors, or developer assistants. Instead of generating generic code, your assistant becomes aware of SAP-specific frameworks like UI5, CAP (CDS), and Fiori Tools ‚Äî helping you scaffold, lint, and maintain projects with accuracy.

What Are MCP Servers?

Think of an MCP server as a ‚Äúknowledge bridge‚Äù between your AI tool (like a code assistant) and your SAP development environment.
Each server provides domain-specific capabilities:

  • UI5 MCP Server ‚Äì for scaffolding, linting, and guiding UI5/Fiori app development.
  • CDS MCP Server ‚Äì for CAP projects, offering CDS modeling, service generation, and best-practice checks.
  • Fiori MCP Server ‚Äì for managing Fiori elements, annotations, and page templates.

Together, these servers create a unified developer experience ‚Äî where AI understands SAP architecture and frameworks natively.

Understanding the Core Components of MCP

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is built around three main components that work together to connect AI systems with useful tools and data sources:

  1. MCP Server ‚Äì provides tools, resources, and prompts

  2. MCP Client ‚Äì acts as the bridge between the LLM and the MCP Server

  3. MCP Host ‚Äì the environment or application that brings it all together (e.g., Claude Desktop, Cursor, VS Code extensions)

Let‚Äôs explore how these parts interact to power intelligent, context-aware development.


MCP Server ‚Äì The Tool and Data Provider

The MCP Server is the heart of the ecosystem.
It‚Äôs a program that exposes capabilities the AI (LLM) can use ‚Äî such as tools, resources, or prompt templates.

An MCP Server can provide:

  • Tools ‚Äì executable functions (for example, fetching data from a database or scaffolding a project)

  • Resources ‚Äì reusable files or datasets frequently accessed by AI

  • Prompts ‚Äì pre-defined, high-quality prompts for interacting with other AI services

Unlike a traditional API server, the MCP Server can run locally on your machine or be deployed remotely in the cloud.
When the LLM identifies a need for a specific function, it calls the corresponding tool from the MCP Server, retrieves the data, and uses it to complete the user‚Äôs request.

MCP Client ‚Äì The Communication Bridge

The MCP Client connects the LLM to one or more MCP Servers.
It handles all message routing between them, ensuring smooth and structured communication.

Its main responsibilities are:

  • Receiving requests from the LLM

  • Forwarding them to the relevant MCP Server

  • Returning the server‚Äôs output back to the LLM

Think of it as the ‚Äúmessenger‚Äù that makes sure the AI can talk to the right tools without needing to know the technical details of how those tools work.

 

MCP Host ‚Äì The User‚Äôs Interaction Layer

The MCP Host is any environment or application that integrates both an LLM and an MCP Client.
Popular examples include Claude Desktop, Cursor, and VS Code extensions.

These hosts provide the user interface ‚Äî what you actually interact with ‚Äî while the MCP Client quietly connects to one or more MCP Servers behind the scenes.
This setup lets you extend an AI model‚Äôs abilities with domain-specific tools, all within your familiar development environment.

MCP Workflow

The three roles mentioned above ultimately form an AI application built on MCP.

Quick Setup

You can install any of these servers globally or within your project.
All are available on npm under the @cap-js and @ui5 scopes.

# Install MCP servers
npm install -g @ui5/mcp-server @cap-js/mcp-server @SAP/fiori-mcp-server

To register them with your IDE or AI tool (like VS Code with MCP support):

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "@ui5/mcp-server": {
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@ui5/mcp-server"]
    },
    "@cap-js/mcp-server": {
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@cap-js/mcp-server"]
    },
    "@sap/fiori-mcp-server": {
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["@sap/fiori-mcp-server"]
    }
  }
}

This setting will be required in the file -> MCP(Project Folder) -> .vscode -> mcp.json



That‚Äôs it ‚Äî your environment is now MCP-enabled.

 

Sample Command References

For a given sample Project I ran the following commands. Attaching the output screenshots.

cds-mcp analyse the data models in form of entities

The cds-mcp server internally ran:

#Input
{
  "kind": "entity",
  "projectPath": "../CloudStorage/OneDrive-SAPSE/Documents/MCP"
}

 

#Output
[{
  "kind": "entity",
  "@cds.persistence.table": true,
  "@cds.autoexpose": true,
  "@UI.Identification": [
    { "Value": { "=": "name" } }
  ],
  "@cds.odata.valuelist": true,
  "includes": [
    "sap.common.CodeList",
    "recruitment.management.MasterData"
  ],
  "elements": {
    "name": {
      "@title": "{i18n>Name}",
      "localized": true,
      "type": "cds.String",
      "length": 255,
      "@Common.Label": "{i18n>Name}"
    },
    "descr": {
      "@title": "{i18n>Description}",
      "localized": true,
      "type": "cds.String",
      "length": 1000,
      "@Common.Label": "{i18n>Description}"
    },
    "ID": {
      "key": true,
      "type": "cds.String",
      "length": 20,
      "$location": {
        "file": "db/masterdata.cds",
        "line": 23,
        "col": 9
      }
    },
    "texts": {
      "type": "cds.Composition",
      "cardinality": { "max": "*" },
      "target": "recruitment.management.YesNo.texts",
      "on": [
        { "ref": ["texts", "ID"] },
        "=",
        { "ref": ["ID"] }
      ]
    },
    "localized": {
      "type": "cds.Association",
      "target": "recruitment.management.YesNo.texts",
      "on": [
        { "ref": ["localized", "ID"] },
        "=",
        { "ref": ["ID"] },
        "and",
        { "ref": ["localized", "locale"] },
        "=",
        { "ref": ["$user", "locale"] }
      ]
    }
  },
  "$location": {
    "file": "db/masterdata.cds",
    "line": 22,
    "col": 8
  },
  "$localized": true,
  "name": "recruitment.management.YesNo"
}]

Please add an SAP Fiori elements list report app to my CAP project.

The ui5Mcp server internally:

#Input
{
  "appNamespace": "recruitment.management.yesno",
  "basePath": "../CloudStorage/OneDrive-SAPSE/Documents/MCP/app",
  "typescript": true,
  "runNpmInstall": true,
  "oDataV4Url": "/odata/v4",
  "oDataEntitySet": "YesNo"
}

 

#Output
Successfully created a SAPUI5 TypeScript application inside
../CloudStorage/OneDrive-SAPSE/Documents/MCP/app/recruitment.management.yesno
(Namespace: recruitment.management.yesno
Framework: SAPUI5 1.141.1) and npm install was executed.
Note that the BaseController has no onInit function, so do not try to call super.onInit() in the MainController when adding code.
Note that in CAP projects you MUST NOT use npm start of this UI5 app, as doing this and opening it on port 8080 will not allow the app to load any data. Instead, you MUST use cds watch in the project root to start the server. The new app is then automatically served at /recruitment.management.yesno/index.html.
Note that the table in the Main view has no columns and the Form has no fields, as an OData service and entity was provided, but no properties were specified and none could be found automatically.
The generated files inside
../OneDrive-SAPSE/Documents/MCP/app/recruitment.management.yesno
are:

entry.content:
Hi Community,

 

"An MCP Server can provide:

  • Tools ‚Äì executable functions (for example, fetching data from a database or scaffolding a project)

  • Resources ‚Äì reusable files or datasets frequently accessed by AI

  • Prompts ‚Äì pre-defined, high-quality prompts for interacting with other AI services

Unlike a traditional API server, the MCP Server can run locally on your machine or be deployed remotely in the cloud.
When the LLM identifies a need for a specific function, it calls the corresponding tool from the MCP Server, retrieves the data, and uses it to complete the user‚Äôs request."

 

Thanks for you selfless sharing, it really help us a lot.

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let‚Äôs implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order‚Äôs header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: üöÄ What‚Äôs New in Floorplan Manager (FPM) for Web Dynpro ABAP in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

When it comes to the design of web-based user interfaces, SAP truly has a rich history. A great example is the EPM Purchase Order Demo (FPM/WDA application S_EPM_FPM_PO) (see Figure 1):

Figure 1: Application S_EPM_FPM_PO ‚Äì Design evolution over the years

Design themes such as Tradeshow, Corbusier, Belize, or Quartz are well known to many developers. But the journey doesn‚Äôt end there ‚Äî it continues toward new Horizons and compliance with the WCAG 2.2 Accessibility Standard.

In the latest releases, several new features have been added to the Floorplan Manager (FPM) / Web Dynpro ABAP framework, driven by customer feedback, SAP design standards, and general product evolution. With the ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 (on-premise, private cloud, and public cloud editions), we are delivering several enhancements that can be activated easily ‚Äî either automatically through delivery or manually with minimal configuration or coding effort.

Page Header UIBBs & Object Page Mode

In one of my previous blogs on S/4HANA 2023, üëâ Team FPM: How to Render an FPM Overview Page to Look Like a SAP Fiori Object Page, I introduced the Object Page Mode for the Overview Page (OVP) floorplan.

This mode allows you to render an FPM Overview Page application like a Fiori Object Page. Combined with a Page Header UIBB, you get a dynamic object header that automatically expands and collapses while scrolling. You can also pin the header to keep it fixed. You can easily try this out in the Search Page of the EPM Purchase Order Demo (see Figure 2).

Figure 2: S_EPM_FPM_PO with Page Header, Pin and List Item Navigation

 

The new List-Item Navigation lets users navigate to a Purchase Order‚Äôs detail page in a Fiori-compliant way. On the detail page, the Object Page Mode provides faster and more precise scrolling to specific screen areas (sections or UIBBs) using the Anchor Bar or Navigation Bar (see Figure 4).

Figure 3: Purchase Order Detail Page with Anchor Bar

Configuration

  • Object Page Mode is activated in the General Settings as a Floorplan Mode (see Figure 4).
  • To use a dynamic object header, define a Page Header Area in the layout and add Page Header UIBBs.

Figure 4: Object Page Mode setting in FLUID for OVP Floorplan S_EPM_UX_PO_OVP

In the List or Tree UIBB, a List-Item Navigation corresponds to rendering a Link-To-Action column differently. You can achieve this by checking Render as Navigation Column in the column configuration (see Figure 5).

Figure 5: Setting ‚ÄúPurchase Order ID‚Äù as Navigation Column in FLUID for List UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_SEARCH_LIST_CFG

Additional Remarks

Some OVP floorplan features may behave differently in Object Page Mode. This can affect:

  • Header rendering
  • UIBB Selector and Page Master splitter control
  • Section and UIBB stacking
  • Personalization and panel behavior

However, Power User Modes allow overriding some restrictions ‚Äî such as enabling drag-and-drop for UIBBs, expanding and collapsing panels, or rearranging layout elements.

CSS Grid Layout & WCAG 2.2 Compliance

Another major improvement is the WCAG 2.2-compliant rendering of forms. We‚Äôve significantly enhanced the responsiveness of the Form/Repeater UIBB (GL2) by adopting a CSS Grid Layout.

This ensures that forms remain usable and readable ‚Äî even at screen widths as low as 320px (mobile phone format) ‚Äî without horizontal scrolling (see Figure 6).

 Figure 6: ‚ÄúPurchase Order Details‚Äù form in different screen sizes

In the configuration editor (FLUID), you can enable the CSS Grid layout at General Settings ‚Üí Layout Design Type ‚Üí Responsive (see Figure 7).

Figure 7: FLUID configuration for Form UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_HEADER_FORM_CFG

Message Toasts & Invisible Alerts

In this context, it‚Äôs worth mentioning the Message Toast and Invisible Alert features, which enhance both usability and accessibility. A Message Toast is a small, non-disruptive popup for success messages that disappears automatically after a few seconds (see Figure 8). The  IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER ABAP interface now provides the REPORT_MESSAGE_TOAST method for this purpose. You can also enable a Toast Mode globally with the SET_TOAST_MODE( IV_TOAST_MODE = GC_TOAST_MODE-ENABLED ) method,  ensuring that messages of severity Success (S) are displayed as toasts by default (see also SAP Help Portal).

Figure 8: ‚ÄúData Saved‚Äù Toast in S_EPM_FPM_PO

An Invisible Alert, on the other hand, is used to inform screen reader users about content changes that are visible but not triggered by them ‚Äî ensuring WCAG 2.2 compliance. Use the REPORT_INVISIBLE_ALERT method from the IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER interface for this purpose.

üîôFLP Back Navigation

Finally, let us introduce Back Navigation in the SAP Fiori Launchpad (FLP).

You can now configure where the FLP back button should navigate to. By default, it goes back to the previous application, but often it‚Äôs more useful to return to the previous page within the same application. For example, when navigating from a main page to an edit page, you likely want the back button to return to the main page of the same object. Further details are available in SAP Help Portal.

‚úÖSummary

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Floorplan Manager for Web Dynpro ABAP continues its evolution toward:

  • A Fiori-consistent Object Page experience
  • Improved accessibility (WCAG 2.2)
  • More responsive layouts
  • Enhanced user feedback mechanisms (message toasts, invisible alerts)
  • Smarter navigation handling in the Fiori Launchpad

These innovations make it easier than ever for FPM-based applications to deliver a modern, accessible, and consistent user experience ‚Äî across all S/4HANA deployment options.

Thank you for reading ‚Äî and see you next time! üòä

Hello,

If your employees are assigned to company codes that are located outside Egypt, then you need to install the appropriate localization for these companies countries. The basis consultant can add the required packages.

If you can't find the required localization, then the only option is to use International version (PC00_M99_CALC).

Finally, the multi-currency payroll isn't standard option in SAP payroll due to financial and legal compliance.

entry.content:

And the Database of legacy system is MSSQL.
For this, we have to check how to create DB Link between the S4hana and MSSQL on legacy cloud.
Please tell me step by step how to create a DB Link between the S4hana on PCE and MSSQL on legacy cloud.

 

For example,
   1. Create a new entry on T-Code : DBCO
   2. Create a new service request on SAP for Me for opening the outbound port to MSSQL Server.
        (Please let me know the name of service request I should select.)
   3. Test the DB connections

Or please let me know what information is needed to create a DBCO.

 

It's a very serious and important thing.
I look forward to your prompt response.

 

Thanks!


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to create a DB link to an MSSQL DB(Java_Legacy) s...
entry.content:
Please refer to the following steps:

Database Link Setup: S/4HANA to MSSQL on Azure Project Overview

  • Source System: S/4HANA on Private Cloud Edition
  • Target System: Legacy MSSQL Database on Azure
  • Objective: Establish database connectivity for data integration

Prerequisites and Information Required Network Requirements

  • Source S/4HANA system network details (IP ranges, subnets)
  • Target MSSQL server IP/hostname on Azure
  • Port numbers for MSSQL connectivity (typically 1433 for default instance)
  • Firewall rules and security groups configuration between S/4 and Azure

Database Connection Parameters

  • MSSQL server instance name (default or named instance)
  • Database name on the target system
  • Authentication method (SQL Server Authentication recommended)
  • Service account credentials with appropriate database permissions
  • Connection string format based on instance type, see note https://me.sap.com/notes/3260340

SAP System Information

  • S/4HANA system ID and client number
  • Basis administrator contact for coordination
  • Current kernel version and patch level

Step-by-Step Implementation Process

Phase 1: Network Connectivity Setup

  1. Verify network connectivity between S/4HANA and Azure MSSQL
  2. Configure Azure network security groups to allow inbound connections
  3. Test basic network connectivity using telnet to the MSSQL port

Phase 2: SAP Service Request Process

Phase 3: Database Link Configuration

  1. Transaction DBCO Configuration

    • Access T-Code DBCO in your S/4HANA system
    • Create new database connection entry
    • Configure connection parameters based on MSSQL instance type, see note https://me.sap.com/notes/3260340
    • Set database type as "MSS" for Microsoft SQL Server

  2. Connection Parameters Setup

    • Database ID: Unique identifier for your connection
    • Database type: MSS (Microsoft SQL Server)
    • Host name: Azure MSSQL server hostname or IP
    • Port: 1433 (default) or specific port for named instances
    • Database name: Target database name on MSSQL server

Phase 4: Authentication Configuration

  1. Configure database user credentials with appropriate permissions
  2. Set up secure connection parameters
  3. Configure SSL/TLS encryption if required by security policies

Phase 5: Testing and Validation

  1. Connection Testing

    • Test connection via DBCO transaction
    • Verify connectivity status and resolve any errors
    • Check system logs for connection issues

  2. Functional Testing

    • Execute sample SELECT queries to verify data access
    • Test data retrieval performance
    • Validate connection stability under load

entry.title: RAP Later Numbering of multiple instances; matching child entries to parent entries
entry.content:
I have a BDEF that uses late numbering and looks as follows:

managed implementation in class /ipn/bp_i_checklisttype unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for /IPN/I_ChecklistType alias ChecklistType
persistent table eam_cl_cu_type
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
late numbering
{
  create;
  field (readonly) ChecklistType;
  update;
  delete;
  association _Text { create; }
  mapping for eam_cl_cu_type
  {
    ChecklistType = cl_type;
    Inactive = inactive;
  }
}

define behavior for /IPN/I_ChecklistTypeText alias ChecklistTypeText
persistent table EAM_CL_CU_TYPT
lock dependent by _ChecklistType
authorization dependent by _ChecklistType
late numbering
{
  update;
  field (readonly:update) ChecklistType, Language;
  delete;
  association _ChecklistType;
  mapping for EAM_CL_CU_TYPT
  {
    ChecklistType = cl_type;
    Language = spras;
    ChecklistTypeText = cl_type_text;
  }
}

The problem is, when I try and create more than one instance at once, e.g. with the following test code:

    MODIFY ENTITY /ipn/i_checklisttype
      CREATE FIELDS ( inactive )
      WITH VALUE #(
          ( %cid = 'cid1' %control-inactive = if_abap_behv=>mk-on  inactive = '' )
          ( %cid = 'cid2' %control-inactive = if_abap_behv=>mk-on  inactive = '' )
       )
       CREATE BY \_text
       FIELDS ( language checklisttypetext ) "ChecklistType
       WITH VALUE #(
            ( %cid_ref = 'cid1' %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid1.1' language = sy-langu checklisttypetext = 'Test created with EML' ) ) )
            ( %cid_ref = 'cid2' %target = VALUE #( ( %cid = 'cid2.1' language = sy-langu checklisttypetext = 'Test created with EML' ) ) )

       )
      FAILED   DATA(mod_failed)
      REPORTED DATA(mod_reported)
      MAPPED   DATA(mod_mapped).

When it reaches the ADJUST_NUMBERS method in the implementation class, there is no reliable way to tie back the child entries (ChecklistTypeText) to the respective headers (ChecklistType).

In the example above, it is not a problem, since there is one child (text) entry per header, but if I were to have multiple child entries per header, I would not be able to tell which child belongs to which header.

The only identifier that is passed along to the ADJUST_NUMBERS method in the MAPPED structure is a GUID in %PID, but this is unique on every record, so it does not allow me to tie back an individual child to its header.

entry.title: Re: It‚Äôs not clear which changes need to be finalized bef...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

  1. Only the Tax Box Mappings for IMG VCL_FOT_ATR (configuration activity: Maintain Tax Box Mapping for Advanced Tax Return [103188]) and IMG V_FOT_TBS2 (configuration activity: Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure [103011]) must be released. All other settings are not relevant for the migration in the development system. However, the overall country settings must be available in the other systems, before you can start the migration there. For more information regarding the configuration locks please read https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-sap/registration-for-indirect-taxation-abroad-rita-in-2302-a-pragmatic-approach/ba-p/13561685
  2. 'configuration project' is a term used for the 2SL setup. For the 3SL setup, it means that the CBC transports and the fine tuning transports that contain the objects mentioned above must be released.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Security: Integrating Microsoft Sentinel
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition now integrated with Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP 

This blog was co-authored with Martin Pankraz (SAP Security PM, Microsoft) 

In the shared responsibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, most of the security tasks are handled by the cloud service provider ‚Äì SAP in this case. However, in order to obtain a comprehensive picture of your security posture and for comprehensive threat detection, certain information from the application is also needed. For this, SAP provides APIs for security relevant data - such as the Security Audit Log when we‚Äôre speaking about event driven data, but also more static APIs to establish a security dashboard are provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  

Providing this information, however, is ‚Äì quite literally ‚Äì only half of the story. In order to make sense of this information, the receiving solution needs to make sense of the data provided, combine it with relevant data from other systems within the landscape and correlate information with each other. This solution also needs to understand the application that provides the information, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in this case.  

This is why we‚Äôre especially thrilled to announce the Microsoft Sentinel for SAP integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - a cloud-native integration that brings real-time threat detection, investigation, and response to your SAP environment.

Why This Matters  

With Microsoft Sentinel as the receiving end of the security relevant APIs that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides, customers receive a lightweight, scalable, compliant, and AI ready approach to integrate SAP telemetry into their enterprise security operations. 

Our integration delivers exactly that: 

  • Agentless deployment for faster onboarding. 
  • Unified security operations across SAP and non-SAP systems. 
  • Compliance-ready log retention at a fraction of traditional costs. 

What This Release Offers 

  1. 1. AI enabled unified Security Operations 
  • Correlate SAP Cloud events with enterprise telemetry in Microsoft Sentinel Solution for SAP and Microsoft Defender XDR ready for Microsoft Security Copilot. 
  • Use prebuilt analytics rules, workbooks, and SOAR playbooks to detect and respond to threats like:  
  • Privilege escalations 
  • Unauthorized configuration changes 
  • Suspicious financial transactions 
  1. 2. Compliance-Ready Log Retention 
  • Store SAP logs cost-efficient in Microsoft Sentinel Data Lake for up to 12 years. 
  • Support threat hunting involving SAP on the Sentinel Data lake through KQL jobs. 

Key Benefits 

  • Faster Deployment: Go live in hours, not weeks. 
  • Future-Proof: Built on SAP‚Äôs strategic integration approach using APIs. 
  • Security at Scale: Detect and respond to threats across your entire SAP landscape. 

How It Works 

  1. Deploy the Microsoft Sentinel integration package in SAP Integration Suite. 
  2. Configure your Microsoft Sentinel workspace to start ingesting SAP logs. 
  3. Activate prebuilt content for instant visibility and protection. SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Üí SAP Integration Suite ‚Üí Microsoft Sentinel 

What‚Äôs Next 

  • General Availability after the current preview phase. 
  • Upcoming enhancements: Expansion of protection scope to additional communication scenarios provided by SAP. 

Getting Started 

Activate SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Microsoft Sentinel Integration | Azure portal from the Sentinel Content Hub. Provide your connection details for communication scenario 750 and you are good to go. 

Once deployed, we recommend to check AryaG‚Äôs series giving details on how to move to production 

Final Words 

#Kudos to the amazing engineering teams on both sides and our incredible community contributors! 

That's a wrap. Remember: bringing SAP under the protection of your central SIEM isn't just a checkbox - it's essential for comprehensive security and compliance across your entire IT estate. 

Cheers, Patrick & Martin

entry.title: beforeOpenContextMenu is not firing when right-clicking on a group header in sap.ui.table.Analytical
entry.content:
Hi,

I am using an SAPUI5 Analytical Table where grouping is implemented at one level.
When I right-click on a group header, the context menu opens with options such as Ungroup Level and Ungroup All.
Since I am using only one grouping level, I would like to hide one of these options (for example, Ungroup Level).
To achieve this, I tried using the beforeOpenContextMenu event to modify the menu items dynamically. However, this event does not trigger when right-clicking on the group header.
On the other hand, the attachColumnSelect event is triggered correctly when right-clicking on a column header (for sorting and filtering), and I am able to hide unwanted menu items there.
I expect similar behavior when right-clicking on the group header to customize that context menu as well.

Steps to Reproduce:
Use an Analytical Table (sap.ui.table.AnalyticalTable) with one-level grouping enabled.
Right-click on a column header ‚Üí attachColumnSelect triggers correctly.
Right-click on a group header (e.g., ‚ÄúCompany Code = XXXX‚Äù) ‚Üí context menu appears with Ungroup Level and Ungroup All options.
Observe that the beforeOpenContextMenu event does not trigger.

Expected Behavior:
When the user right-clicks on a group header, the beforeOpenContextMenu event should trigger so that developers can modify or hide specific menu options (for example, remove Ungroup Level when only one grouping level is used).

Actual Behavior:
The context menu is displayed when right-clicking on a group header, but the beforeOpenContextMenu event is not fired.

Code Snippet Used:
const oTable = this.byId("dynamicTable");
// Works on column header right-click
oTable.attachColumnSelect((oEvent) => {
    console.log(oEvent);
});

// Not triggered on group header right-click
oTable.attachBeforeOpenContextMenu((oEvent) => {
    console.log("Context menu event triggered:", oEvent);
});

Please let me know if I am missing anything or if there is an alternative way to capture the context menu event on group headers to modify or remove menu options dynamically.

Regards,
Sridevi

entry.title: Re: Show percentage of row totals in story report
entry.content:
Hello jo21,

The only way I can imagine right now, is to create separate calculated measures. So instead of putting the Overall Performance (or Potential) Rating Description into the columns of the cross-tab table, you can create one  restricted measure for each of them. In another calculated measure you can now sum these values up to get the subtotal. And each of the %-columns can now be calculated by the number per Rating  divided by the subtotal column.

I understand if this is not the best idea in case you have a lot of values in the columns, but in your case there are only 3, which means 7 calculated measures can cover your request.
